awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:   Computational Thermochemistry of Compounds
awd_abstract_narration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award supports computational and data enabled research and education on the thermochemistry of materials. Despite its importance, both fundamental and practical, measured enthalpies of formation are currently available only for a fraction of known compounds. The PIs will perform large-scale computations of quantitatively accurate enthalpies of formation for a significant fraction, of the order of 30,000-40,000, of known compounds and create a publicly available database.  They will use data mining to extract quantitative relations among formation enthalpy values and physical and chemical properties describing both the compounds and their elemental constituents.
These goals will be achieved by employing a computational approach, called FERE, for computing accurate enthalpies of formation using only structure and composition as inputs. Having such a database will reveal interesting relationships between formation enthalpy values and physical and chemical properties of compounds and their elemental constituents which are so far undiscovered. Discovering those relations by applying modern data mining techniques is an equally important goal of the research. 

Approximately ~150,000 compounds known today fall into the category of "incomplete structural information."  A recently developed computational tool, the FPASS structure solver, is capable of providing structures of compounds where only partial experimental information is available. The PIs will begin solving some of these unknown crystal structures, thereby allowing FERE calculations of the formation enthalpies, and continuous expansion of the database.

The PIs also aim to develop a tutorial "Materials for Sustainable Energies: Linking Experiment and Computations" geared toward graduate students interested in energy-related materials, as well as early-career faculty members and industrial participants.

NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award supports computational and data enabled research and education on the thermochemistry of materials. The enthalpy of formation, the energy needed to form a compound out of its elemental constituents, is one of the fundamental quantities characterizing a material. It is also of great practical value and essential for many aspects of materials science and chemical engineering. However, measured enthalpies of formation are currently available only for a fraction of known compounds. This award supports large-scale computations of quantitatively accurate enthalpies of formation for a significant fraction of known compounds, on the order of 30,000 - 40,000, creation of a publicly available database, and data mining to extract quantitative relations among formation enthalpy values and physical and chemical properties describing both the compounds and their elemental constituents. 

This will be achieved by employing a recently developed method, named FERE, for computing accurate enthalpies of formation, and applying it to known compounds with known crystal structures. The database will be continuously updated with the formation enthalpy values of compounds with partially known crystal structure by utilizing a computational tool that is capable of providing structures of compounds where only partial experimental information is available. The data mining of the resulting database will reveal material/property relationships and provide deeper understanding of trends in formation enthalpy values across the periodic table. Once created the database will fill large gaps in the literature and offer numerous possibilities for studying materials thermodynamics and thermochemistry.

This project is multidisciplinary in the sense that it draws on computational techniques developed in the physics, materials science, and chemistry communities to tackle problems of relevance to a wide range of disciplines. This project will train a new generation of researchers conversant in all these disciplines through mentorship of graduate and undergraduate students. The PIs also aim to develop a tutorial "Materials for Sustainable Energies: Linking Experiment and Computations" geared toward graduate students interested in energy-related materials, as well as early-career faculty members and industrial participants. Furthermore, this effort will extend beyond the core students through workshops targeted for science teachers from predominantly minority and/or underprivileged K-6 schools.

por.por_cntn:
This collaborative project entails computational and data-driven research and education on the topic of thermochemistry of materials. The focal point of the work is the enthalpy of formation, a physical quantity defined as the energy needed to form a compound (material) out of its elemental constituents. The enthalpy of formation is one of the fundamental quantities characterizing a material and its stability relative to decomposition and is of great practical value and essential for many aspects of materials science and chemical engineering. However, measured enthalpies of formation are available for only a fraction of known compounds. This project directly addressed the lack of measured values by conducting large-scale (high-throughput) calculations of quantitatively accurate enthalpies of formation and the resulting assessment of thermochemical stability of materials for a significant fraction of known compounds. This data, covering more than 25,000 material systems, has been organized in a database that is open and available to general public. In addition, significant efforts have been invested in understanding relationships between enthalpies of formation and physical and chemical properties describing both the compounds and their elemental constituents using modern data mining and machine learning techniques. Also, we demonstrated the usefulness of having calculated enthalpies of formation in a range of different materials science problems including discovery of new materials, defect formation energetics, and applications in energy materials development. This work was achieved by employing a method developed by the PI Stevanovic and others, named FERE, for computing accurate enthalpies of formation, and applying it to known inorganic compounds with known crystal structure.

 In the context of intellectual merits, specific outcomes of this project include:

  1. Successful execution of high-throughput calculations of compound enthalpies of formation for approximately 25,000 individual materials,
  2. Creation of a public database of computed enthalpies of formation and the resulting thermochemical stability available via materials.nrel.gov website,
  3. Development of quantitative relationships between calculated enthalpies of formation and quantities describing crystal structure and chemical composition of compounds using data mining and machine learning tools. This advances our understanding of how chemistry and structure influence complex materials’ properties and allows almost effortless prediction of the enthalpies of formation and stability of systems that are not in the database (hypothetical or not well characterized materials) and facilitates predictions of new materials,
  4. Development of quantitative understanding of how enthalpy of formation influences other relevant properties of materials such as formation energetics of oxygen vacancies in metal oxides, which improves our ability to identify suitable oxide materials for application in solar thermal fuel (Hydrogen) production,
  5. Finally, the first successful automation of defect calculations which holds significant potential to accelerate design and discovery of new material solutions for applications that critically rely on defects and doping including a broad range of semiconductor applications, thermoelectric, thermochemical fuel production, and other.

 In the context of broader impacts, it is important to emphasize the present transformation of materials science from mainly intuition driven (in which computations predominantly take an explanatory role), to data-driven (where computations are used to provide reliable guidance to future experimental efforts). The revolution is largely fueled by the availability of calculated enthalpies of formation of materials. The outcomes of this project contribute in a significant way to the transformation of modern computational materials science that is already resulting in substantial benefits to the society as evidenced by an increasing number of computationally guided discoveries of new and promising materials. Further, this project is truly multidisciplinary in the sense that it draws on computational techniques developed in the physics, materials science, and chemistry communities to tackle problems of relevance to a wide range of disciplines. It trained a new generation of researchers conversant in all these disciplines through mentorship of undergraduate and graduate students as well as postdoctoral researchers. Furthermore, the techniques and insights gained from the research, in addition to being broadly disseminated through public databases, scientific publications and at conferences, became an integral part of course materials and are used as an effective educational tool in the courses thought by the PIs.
